removals.reasoning: Outer parentheses around a cast expression used as a function argument are redundant; (double*)data is the standard, simpler form.
Same as above: extra outer parentheses around the cast are unnecessary.
Remove redundant outer parentheses around the cast inside the function call.
Remove redundant outer parentheses around the cast inside the function call.
Remove redundant outer parentheses around the cast inside the function call.
The extra outer parentheses around the cast in the call are unnecessary.
The outer parentheses around the cast expression passed to free are redundant; keep the cast syntax but drop the superfluous outer pair.
Remove redundant outer parentheses around the cast inside free(); the inner casts must remain for correct typing.
Drop the unnecessary outer parentheses around the cast used as the call argument.
Remove the redundant outer parentheses around a cast expression used as a function argument.
Parentheses around the index expression are stylistically unnecessary; data[i * n + j] is clearer and equivalent.

Several redundant parentheses here: use (double)i and (double)j for casts (no inner parentheses around the variable) and the surrounding grouping is unnecessary because * and / have appropriate precedence and associativity.
Parentheses around a single variable passed as a function argument are redundant; fmt_double_space is sufficient.
Array-index parentheses are unnecessary; corr[i * m + j] is clearer and equivalent.
Casting the integer literal 20 to int is redundant: 20 is already an int literal. Removing the cast simplifies the expression without changing behavior.
Parentheses around a single variable in a function argument are unnecessary.
Same as above: remove redundant parentheses around the variable passed to fprintf.

The inner parentheses are redundant when combined with the outer grouping. Simplifying to (num + factor - 1) / factor (or leaving a single pair around the whole numerator) preserves intended precedence and improves readability.
Cast syntax doesn't need an extra pair around the variable; (double)n is the simple, equivalent form.
The outer parentheses around the right-hand side are unnecessary; the expression reads more clearly without them.
Remove redundant parentheses around the array index expression.

removals.expression: ((data[(i * m + j)] - mean[j]) * (data[(i * m + j)] - mean[j]))
removals.replacement: (data[i * m + j] - mean[j]) * (data[i * m + j] - mean[j])
removals.reasoning: Keep the parentheses that are required to ensure subtraction happens before multiplication, but drop outer/redundant parentheses and simplify array indexing for clarity.
Use the standard cast form without extra parentheses around the variable.
Index parentheses are not needed; the simpler form improves readability.
The parentheses around this subtraction used as the right-hand side are redundant; subtraction has lower precedence than assignment so the meaning is unchanged.
Remove the unnecessary parentheses around the operand of the cast.
Simplify array indexing by removing unnecessary parentheses.
Outer parentheses around the division are unnecessary; keep the parentheses that group the denominator expression (sqrt_n * stddev[j]).
Array index grouping parentheses are redundant.
Arithmetic has higher precedence than comparison, so i < m - 1 is parsed as intended; the extra parentheses around the subtraction are not needed.
Remove unnecessary parentheses around the index expression.
Simplify indexing by removing redundant parentheses.
Drop redundant parentheses around the index to improve readability.

Multiple nested parentheses around a straightforward arithmetic expression are redundant; simplifying keeps the same semantics while improving clarity. (If desired, this can be further simplified algebraically, e.g. m * m - 1.)
No change — shown for context (no redundant parentheses in this call).
